chapter.htmlHeader: How should I assess a woman with menopausal symptoms?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
If a woman has suspected menopause, perimenopause, or premature ovarian insufficiency (POI):

  • Ask about:
    • The symptoms of menopause, including nature, frequency, duration, time of day, and their severity and impact on quality of life.
    • Other potential causes of amenorrhoea, including pregnancy. See the CKS topic on Amenorrhoea for more information.
    • Lifestyle factors, such as smoking, alcohol, exercise, and nutrition.
    • The need for ongoing or future contraception. See the CKS topic on Contraception - assessment for more information.
    • Smear status and engagement with national screening programmes (if appropriate). See the CKS topics on Cervical screening, Breast screening, and Bowel screening for more information.
    • Family history including premature menopause or POI, venous thromboembolism, or hormone-dependent cancer including breast cancer. See the CKS topic on Breast cancer - managing FH for more information.
    • Her treatment goals, including non-pharmacological, non-hormonal, or hormonal drug options.
    • Previous treatments tried, effectiveness, and tolerability (if any).
    • Current medications that may affect the choice of treatments available.
    • Co-morbid conditions that may affect the choice and safety of hormonal treatment options, depending on the woman's wishes, such as:
      • History of, or increased risk of, cardiovascular disease, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, venous thromboembolism, or stroke disease. See the CKS topics on CVD risk assessment and management, Hypertension - not diabetic, Diabetes - type 2, Deep vein thrombosis, Pulmonary embolism, and Stroke and TIA for more information.
      • History of, or increased risk of, hormone-dependent cancer including breast, endometrial, and ovarian cancer.
      • Previous medical or surgical treatment, including chemotherapy, radiotherapy, hysterectomy, and/or bilateral oophorectomy.
    • Bone health and assess risk of osteoporosis. See the CKS topic on Osteoporosis - prevention of fragility fractures for more information.
  • Examine the woman:
    • Check blood pressure and body mass index (BMI).
    • If there is a sudden change in menstrual pattern, intermenstrual bleeding, postcoital bleeding, or postmenopausal bleeding — assess appropriately and arrange an urgent 2-week referral if a gynaecological cancer is suspected. See the CKS topic on Gynaecological cancers - recognition and referral for more information.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on assessment are based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) clinical guidelines Menopause [NICE, 2019] and Suspected cancer: recognition and referral [NICE, 2017b]; the European Menopause and Andropause Society (EMAS) position statements Maintaining postreproductive health: a care pathway from the European Menopause and Andropause Society (EMAS) [Armeni, 2016], EMAS recommendations for conditions in the workplace for menopausal women [Griffiths, 2016], and Predictors of premature and early natural menopause [Mishra, 2019]; the Endocrine Society clinical practice guideline Treatment of symptoms of the menopause [Stuenkel, 2015]; the American Association of Clinical Endocrinologists (AACE) consensus publication Medical guidelines for clinical practice for the diagnosis and treatment of menopause [Goodman, 2011]; the AACE and American College of Endocrinology (ACE) Position statement on menopause - 2017 update [Cobin, 2017]; the North American Menopause Society position statements on non-hormonal management of vasomotor symptoms [North American Menopause Society, 2015] and on hormonal therapy [North American Menopause Society, 2018]; the Faculty of Sexual and Reproductive Healthcare (FSRH) clinical guideline Contraception for women aged over 40 years [FSRH, 2019]; and expert opinion in a review article on hormonal treatment [Pinkerton, 2020] and in a medical textbook [Rees, 2009].

Clinical features on history taking
  • The recommendation to assess the nature of menopausal symptoms and impact on quality of life is extrapolated from the EMAS position statement [Griffiths, 2016].
  • The recommendation to assess for other causes of amenorrhoea is based on the EMAS position statement [Armeni, 2016].
  • The recommendation to assess for lifestyle factors is based on the EMAS position statement [Armeni, 2016] and the AACE consensus publication, which notes that obesity and smoking can increase risk of venous thromboembolism, which in turn may affect the choice of treatment options available [Goodman, 2011].
  • The recommendation to assess the need for contraception is extrapolated from the FSRH clinical guideline [FSRH, 2019].
  • The recommendation to assess smear status and engagement with other screening programmes is based on the EMAS position statement [Armeni, 2016] and the Endocrine Society clinical practice guideline [Stuenkel, 2015].
  • The recommendation to assess family history including premature menopause and premature ovarian insufficiency (POI) is based on the NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2019] and the EMAS position statement, which notes strong genetic predictors of premature and early menopause [Mishra, 2019].
  • The recommendation to assess the woman's treatment goals is based on the NICE clinical guideline on menopause [NICE, 2019].
  • The recommendation to assess co-morbid conditions that may affect choice of treatment options is based on the EMAS position statement [Armeni, 2016], the AACE consensus publication [Goodman, 2011], the AACE/ACE position statement [Cobin, 2017], the Endocrine Society clinical practice guideline [Stuenkel, 2015], the North American Menopause Society position statement on hormonal therapy [North American Menopause Society, 2018], and expert opinion in a review article [Pinkerton, 2020].
  • The recommendation to assess bone health is based on the Endocrine Society clinical practice guideline [Stuenkel, 2015].
Clinical features on examination
  • The recommendation to check blood pressure and body mass index (BMI) if considering hormonal treatment is based on the EMAS position statement [Armeni, 2016].
  • The recommendation to assess appropriately if there is suspected gynaecological cancer is based on the NICE clinical guideline on suspected cancer [NICE, 2017b].
